case_name: Thakur Bahadur Singh v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Petition filed as Original Jurisdiction Petition No. 200 of 1955 under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 200 of 1955. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 17, 1961 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: St 1961. March 17. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAP., J.-Section 4 of the Rajasthan Land Reforms and Res

facts.text: Rajasthan Land Reforms and Resumption of Jagirs Act, 1952 received assent of President on February 13, 1952 and came into force on February 16, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Before, however, the date of the order according recognition and granting renewal in favour of the petitioner, the Rajasthan Act of 1952 had been passed and having received the assent of the President on February 13, 1952, came into force on publication in the Gazette on February 16, 1952,

facts.text: Thakur Nathu Singh, Jagirdar of Ras, a Scheduled Jagir under Marwar Act, died in July 1946 leaving petitioner Thakur Bahadur Singh as next heir.

anchor.surface_text: Thakur Nathu Singh, the Jagirdar of Ras-a Scheduled Jagir under the Marwar Act died in July 1946 leaving the petitioner, Thakur Bahadur Singh as his next heir. Scheduled Jagirs are, under the Marwar Act, impartable and their line of devolution was prescribed by s. 182 thereof which ran Succession shall be governed in the case of Scheduled Jagirs by the rule of primogeniture.

facts.text: Government recognized petitioner's title to succeed to the jagir and granted renewal by order dated March 18, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The title of the petitioner to succeed to the jagir as the next heir of his father was recognised and a renewal granted in his favour by the Government by an order dated March 18, 1952. Section 190 of the Marwar Act imposes an obligation on a succeeding heir whose title has been recognised and to whom a renewal of the jagir has been granted, to make certain payments.

facts.text: Respondent-State demanded Rs. 30,000 as hukamnama and other fees under Section 190 of Marwar Land Revenue Act, 1949 from petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The amount payable by the petitioner, according to the scale of fees prescribed under the Act, came to Rs. 30,000 and the respondent-State demanded this sum.

facts.text: Petitioner resists demand relying on Section 4(a) of Rajasthan Act claiming hukamnama liability extinguished as it is tribute.

anchor.surface_text: Relying on s. 4 a  of the Rajasthan Act, the petitioner resists the demand of he same made by the respondent-State and impugns the legality of the claim.

facts.text: Petitioner is a Jagirdar under Marwar Act.

anchor.surface_text: it is number in dispute that the petitioner is a Jagirdar and hukamnama regarding which the demand has been made on him- is a demand which is due under an existing Jagir law, viz., the Marwar Act.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court in Thakur Narpat Singh v. State of Rajasthan (ILR 1955 Rajasthan 534) held hukamnama under s.190 Marwar Act not within s.4(a) Rajasthan Act.

anchor.surface_text: The precise question which number arises for our decision came up before the High Court of Rajasthan in 1955 on facts exactly parallel with the case before us and a Bench of that Court held in a case reported as Thakur Narpat Singh v. The State of Rajasthan  1  that hukamnama and the fees payable under s. 190 of the Marwar Act were number within,. 4 a  of the Rajasthan Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that hukamnama is not tribute under s.4 Rajasthan Act and petition fails.

anchor.surface_text: We have thus reached the same companyclusion as the learned Judges of the Rajasthan High Court, though on a different line of reasoning. On the companystruction which we have adopted of the expression tribute in s. 4 of the Rajasthan Act the petitioner can have numberlegal or legitimate grievance against the enforcement of the payment made against him. The petition fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: Scheduled Jagirs under Marwar Act are impartible and devolve by primogeniture per s.182.

anchor.surface_text: Scheduled Jagirs are, under the Marwar Act, impartable and their line of devolution was prescribed by s. 182 thereof which ran Succession shall be governed in the case of Scheduled Jagirs by the rule of primogeniture. The succession, however, was number automatic but had to be recognised by the Government and a renewal granted in favour of the successor before his title to the jagir was perfected.

facts.text: Under Marwar Act s.183-185, grants of Scheduled Jagirs are for life-time, renewed subject to His Highness pleasure, and resumed on death until renewal.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 183-185 of the Marwar Act which are of relevance in this companynection, ran S. 183. All grants of Scheduled Jagirs are only for the life-time of the holder, and numberperson is entitled to succeed to such jagir until his succession is recognized and the grant is renewed in his favour by His Highness. S. 184. Subject always to His Highness pleasure, the grant of a Scheduled Jagir, on the death of the holder, shall be renewed in favour of the person entitled to succeed him in accordance with the provisions of this Act. S. 185 1 . A Scheduled Jagir, on the death of the holder, and until the renewal of the grant in favour of his successor, shall be resumed by the Government and taken under direct management.

facts.text: Section 190 Marwar Act requires succeeding heir to execute Kabuliyat for payment of Hukamnama and other fees within one month of communication of renewal order.

anchor.surface_text: Section 190 of the Marwar Act imposes an obligation on a succeeding heir whose title has been recognised and to whom a renewal of the jagir has been granted, to make certain payments. This section runs S. 190 1 . When succession to a Scheduled Jagir is recognised by His Highness and renewal of the grant ordered, the person in whose favour the grant is ordered to be renewed shall execute within one month of the companymunication to him of the orders, a Kabuliyat for payment of Hukamnama and other fees payable in accordance with sub-sections  2  and  3 .

facts.text: It is common ground that if hukamnama is tribute under s.4 Rajasthan Act, it ceases to be exigible from February 16, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground, subject to a submission of the learned Advocate-General for the respondent-State, which we shall refer to a little later, that if the hukamnama which the petitioner has been required to pay to the Government was a tribute within s. 4 of the Rajasthan Act, it would cease to be exigible and cannot be enforced from and after February 16, 1952,

facts.text: Advocate-General for respondent argued s.4 Rajasthan Act not retrospective, but court did not permit pursuit as not raised in answer.

anchor.surface_text: He sought to urge that s. 4 of the Rajasthan Act was number retrospective and that as the recognition of the title of the Petitioner and the renewal of the grant of the jagir in his favour related back to July 1946 when the succession opened, the Rajasthan Act companyld number be invoked to put an end to the obligation which had accrued years before it came into force numberwithstanding that the orders of recognition and renewal were passed only in March 1952. In the circumstances of this case, however, and also regard being had to the point number having been raised in the answer filed by the State to the writ petition, we did number companysider it proper to permit the Advocate-General to pursue the submission.

facts.text: Hukamnama is a levy for recognition of succession to Scheduled Jagir, not recurring like rekh, rakam, chatund, chakri.

anchor.surface_text: Stated briefly, the ratio of their decision was as follows Under the law governing jagir grants and the tenure on which they are held in Marwar, a hukamnama is a levy chargeable for recognition of the succession of a person to a Scheduled Jagir I.L.R. 1955 Rajasthan 534. of his deceased ancestor. The specific dues, Rekh and Chakri enumerated in the definition of s. 2 r  of the Rajasthan Act are those levied in Marwar, the former being 8 per cent of the gross rental value of an estate and the second the cash equivalent of the obligation to supply horsemen or camelsowars or foot-soldier,-, by Jagirdars dependent upon the value of the estate.

facts.text: Ras is a Scheduled Jagir under Marwar Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thakur Nathu Singh, the Jagirdar of Ras-a Scheduled Jagir under the Marwar Act died in July 1946

facts.text: Marwar Land Revenue Act, 1949 codified earlier law.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of the above provision the petitioner would have been under an obligation to pay to the Government hukamnama under s. 190 of the Marwar Land Revenue Act, 1949  referred to hereafter as the Marwar Act  which companyified the earlier law irk that State.

facts.text: Petition heard with counsel K. Kapoor and Ganpat Rai for petitioner, C. Kasliwal and D. Gupta for respondents.

anchor.surface_text: K. Kapoor and Ganpat Rai, for the petitioner. C. Kasliwal and D. Gupta, for the respondents. St 1961. March 17.

facts.text: Supreme Court reaches same conclusion as Rajasthan High Court that hukamnama not tribute, but on different reasoning.

anchor.surface_text: We have thus reached the same companyclusion as the learned Judges of the Rajasthan High Court, though on a different line of reasoning.
Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights. K. Kapoor and Ganpat Rai, for the petitioner. C. Kasliwal and D. Gupta, for the respondents.

Art. 32 of the Constitution is whether the liability of the petitioner to pay hukamnama, the nature of which we shall explain later, has been extinguished by the provision of the Rajasthan Act above extracted which, as would be seen, turns on whether such a payment could be comprehended within the expression tribute.

anchor.surface_text: Section 190 of the Marwar Act imposes an obligation on a succeeding heir whose title has been recognised and to whom a renewal of the jagir has been granted, to make certain payments. This section runs S. 190 1 . When succession to a Scheduled Jagir is recognised by His Highness and renewal of the grant ordered, the person in whose favour the grant is ordered to be renewed shall execute within one month of the communication to him of the orders, a Kabuliyat for payment of Hukamnama and other fees payable in accordance with sub-sections  2  and  3 .

anchor.surface_text: Scheduled Jagirs are, under the Marwar Act, impartable and their line of devolution was prescribed by s. 182 thereof which ran Succession shall be governed in the case of Scheduled Jagirs by the rule of primogeniture. The succession, however, was not automatic but had to be recognised by the Government and a renewal granted in favour of the successor before his title to the jagir was perfected.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 183-185 of the Marwar Act which are of relevance in this connection, ran S. 183. All grants of Scheduled Jagirs are only for the life-time of the holder, and no person is entitled to succeed to such jagir until his succession is recognized and the grant is renewed in his favour by His Highness.

concepts.unlisted_description: Grants of Scheduled Jagirs for life-time only.

anchor.surface_text: S. 184. Subject always to His Highness pleasure, the grant of a Scheduled Jagir, on the death of the holder, shall be renewed in favour of the person entitled to succeed him in accordance with the provisions of this Act.

anchor.surface_text: S. 185 1 . A Scheduled Jagir, on the death of the holder, and until the renewal of the grant in favour of his successor, shall be resumed by the Government and taken under direct management. Provided that the claimant to succession shall, in the, absence of special orders of His Highness be permitted to retain possession pending orders of His Highness regarding the claim, if he is a direct lineal descendant in the male line of the last holder.

concepts.unlisted_description: Resumption of Scheduled Jagir on death pending renewal.

anchor.surface_text: these were payments due to the ruler in recognition of his sovereign right to the ownership of the land which was statutorily embodied in ss. 169-170 of the Marwar Act which ran S. 169. The ownership of all land vests in His Highness and all jagirs, bhoms, sansans, dolis or similar proprietary interests are held and shall be deemed to be held as grant,- from His Highness.

concepts.unlisted_description: Ownership of land vests in His Highness.

anchor.surface_text: and S. 170. All grants shall be held by the original grantee or his successors during His Highness pleasure. The payments under s. 190 of the Act therefore were not of the same category as the payments enumerated in s. 2  r  of the Rajasthan Act and hence could not be comprehended within the meaning of the expression tribute.

concepts.unlisted_description: Grants held during His Highness' pleasure.

issues.text: whether the liability of the petitioner to pay hukamnama, the nature of which we shall explain later, has been extinguished by the provision of the Rajasthan Act above extracted which, as would be seen, turns on whether such a payment could be comprehended within the expression tribute.

anchor.surface_text: The short question that is raised by this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is whether the liability of the petitioner to pay hukamnama, the nature of which we shall explain later, has been extinguished by the provision of the Rajasthan Act above extracted which, as would be seen, turns on whether such a payment could be comprehended within the expression tribute.

issues.text: whether the liability to pay hukamnama or other fees under s. 190 of the Marwar Act is a tribute from the payment of which the Jagirdars are thus relieved.

anchor.surface_text: The question debated in this petition is whether the liability to pay hukamnama or other fees under s. 190 of the Marwar Act is a tribute from the payment of which the Jagirdars are thus relieved. It is common ground, subject to a submission of the learned Advocate-General for the respondent-State, which we shall refer to a little later, that if the hukamnama which the petitioner has been required to pay to the Government was a tribute within s. 4 of the Rajasthan Act, it would cease to be exigible and cannot be enforced from and after February 16, 1952

issues.text: whether s. 4 of the Rajasthan Act was not retrospective and that as the recognition of the title of the Petitioner and the renewal of the grant of the jagir in his favour related back to July 1946 when the succession opened, the Rajasthan Act could not be invoked to put an end to the obligation which had accrued years before it came into force notwithstanding that the orders of recognition and renewal were passed only in March 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Before doing so, however, it is necessary to advert to a point sought to be raised by the learned Advocate-General for Rajasthan for the respondent which would cut across all this debate. He sought to urge that s. 4 of the Rajasthan Act was not retrospective and that as the recognition of the title of the Petitioner and the renewal of the grant of the jagir in his favour related back to July 1946 when the succession opened, the Rajasthan Act could not be invoked to put an end to the obligation which had accrued years before it came into force notwithstanding that the orders of recognition and renewal were passed only in March 1952.

issues.text: the question of construction posed for our decision may be thus set out: whether the expression 'tribute' as defined in s. 2(r) of the Rajasthan Act, being inclusive, is confined to recurring annual payments like rekh, rakam, chatund, chakri or other charges of a similar nature, or extends to ad hoc payments like hukamnama.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the usual express saving contained in the opening words of s. 2 that the definitions set out are to be applied unless the context otherwise requires, the meaning of the word tribute has to be ascertained from a consideration of the various provisions of the Act and not merely from s. 4(a) of the Act read in the light of the definition. It would be seen that in ultimate analysis the question of construction posed for our decision may be thus set out The four specific enumerated dues in the definition in s. 2(r) are recurring annual payments.

holdings.text: Notwithstanding therefore that the definition in s. 2(r) of the Rajasthan Act is inclusive it appears to us from an examination of the meaning of the word as used in the operative provisions of the Act, that it could refer only to recurring payments which could be said to be attributable to particular years and not to the type of ad hoc payments of which hukamnamas and patta-fees are examples.

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding therefore that the definition in s. 2 r of the Rajasthan Act is inclusive it appears to us from an examination of the meaning of the word as used in the operative provisions of the Act, that it could refer only to recurring payments which could be said to be attrib

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inclusive definition limited by context of entire Act including s.8, Schedule II r.4, Schedule III which use 'tribute' and 'recurring' only for annual payments; dictionary meaning overridden by statutory context and purpose.

holdings.text: On the construction which we have adopted of the expression tribute in s. 4 of the Rajasthan Act the petitioner can have no legal or legitimate grievance against the enforcement of the payment made against him.

anchor.surface_text: On the construction which we have adopted of the expression tribute in s. 4 of the Rajasthan Act the petitioner can have no legal or legitimate grievance against the enforcement of the payment made against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hukamnama is ad hoc payment not falling within 'tribute' as interpreted; thus s.4(a) does not extinguish liability under s.190 Marwar Act.

holdings.text: The petition fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The petition fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's claim that s.4 Rajasthan Act extinguishes hukamnama liability rejected based on interpretation of 'tribute'.

precedents.cited_proposition: Under the law governing jagir grants and the tenure on which they are held in Marwar, a hukamnama is a levy chargeable for recognition of the succession of a person to a Scheduled Jagir
